> Yes, I know it can be worked around : assertFalse(a.equals(b));
> But that's a wart.

if the equals doesn't work, you will only know that it doesn't work, 
without any information about _why_.  If you find yourself writing some 
System.out.println after an assertion failed, this tells you that the 
assertion doesn't give you enough information -> write your own.

> I had always assumed that the JUnit developers had some strong reason
> for overlooking such an obvious thing.  But maybe not.  If not, please
> consider adding assertNotEquals for the next release.

You're the only one responsible for fixing a problem you want to be 
fixed :-)

-Vladimir
